data.question: What is the sequence of the short peptide used in the synthesis of the protein-like two-nanometer-sized channel?
What role does silver(I) play in the assembly of the short peptide into a crystalline structure?
data.answer: Silver(I) coordination induces the folding and assembly processes of the short peptide ligand, leading to the formation of a single crystal composed of polyproline II helices.

data.question: How were the guest molecules encapsulated into the peptide-folded porous crystal?
data.answer: Guest molecules were encapsulated by soaking the crystals in polar solutions of the guest molecules.

What is the effect of the counterion on the crystallization process?
data.answer: The counterion plays an important role in crystallization, although it is easily interchangeable by anion exchange.

data.question: How does the encapsulation of maltopentaose within the large channel A occur?
data.answer: Maltopentaose is encapsulated within channel A by soaking the single crystals in a methanol solution of maltopentaose.

data.question: What is the significance of the PII helix conformation in the assembly of the peptide into a crystalline structure?
data.answer: The PII helix conformation allows the short peptide ligand to be three-dimensionally networked by coordination-driven self-assembly, forming a single crystalline nanostructure.

data.question: How does the size of the nanochannel affect the encapsulation of chiral molecules?
data.answer: The size of the nanochannel allows for the differentiation of guest chirality, with larger channel A showing high enantiomeric excess in the encapsulation of chiral molecules.

data.question: What is the role of hydrogen bonds in the encapsulation of bio-oligomers?
data.answer: Hydrogen bonds between the hydroxy groups on the bio-oligomers and amide carbonyl moieties on peptide 1 along the surface of channel A facilitate the efficient trapping of bio-oligomers.

data.question: What is the effect of solvent choice on the encapsulation of bio-oligomers?
data.answer: The choice of solvent, such as methanol, is crucial for the successful encapsulation of bio-oligomers, indicating that encapsulation is enthalpically driven.

data.question: Is the peptide Gly-Pro-Pro sequence found in natural systems?
data.answer: True, the Gly-Pro-Pro sequence is a unit of collagen, which is found in natural systems.

data.question: Can the peptide-folded porous crystal selectively encapsulate chiral molecules?
data.answer: True, the peptide-folded porous crystal shows moderate to high chiral recognition for chiral molecules.

data.question: Is the conformation of tripeptide ligand 1 in the crystalline state different from the PII helix conformation?
data.answer: False, the conformation of tripeptide ligand 1 in the crystalline state is specifically fixed in the PII helix conformation.

data.question: Are the peptide ligands in the crystalline structure linked by non-directional interactions?
data.answer: False, the peptide ligands are linked by py-AgI-py coordination in a directional N!C-terminal manner.

data.question: Is the crystalline structure capable of encapsulating large bio-oligomeric molecules?
data.answer: True, the crystalline structure is capable of molecular recognition of large bio-oligomeric molecules.

data.question: Does the crystalline structure contain only one type of nanochannel?
data.answer: False, the crystalline structure contains two types of one-dimensional chiral channel.

data.question: Is the yield of the colorless block crystals [(AgBF4)·1]n higher than 50%?
data.answer: False, the yield of the colorless block crystals [(AgBF4)·1]n is 38%.

data.question: Can the counterions in the crystalline network be exchanged without altering the crystal structure?
data.answer: True, the counterions in the crystalline network can be exchanged in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion without altering the crystal structure.
